content.question:
<math alttext="2 F e 2 O 3 solid plus 3 C solid react to produce 4 F e solid plus 3 C O 2 gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>Fe</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>C</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><mn>4</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>Fe</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>
In a blast furnace, the reaction represented above occurs, producing <math alttext="F e solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Fe</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> from its ore, <math alttext="F e 2 O 3 solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Fe</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. The reaction is thermodynamically favorable and based on coupling the two reactions represented below.
<math alttext="2 F e 2 O 3 reacts to produce 4 F e plus 3 O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>Fe</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>→</mo><mn>4</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>Fe</mtext><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="C plus O 2 react to produce C O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C</mtext><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>→</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>
Which of the following identifies a limitation in how the representations above describe a system of coupled reactions?

choices.label: None of the equations are balanced.

The values of <math alttext="delta S naught " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>S</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for each reaction are not shown.

The values of <math alttext="delta G naught" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for each reaction are not shown.
The coupled reactions lack a common intermediate species.

content.answer: The values of <math alttext="delta G naught" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for each reaction are not shown.

skill.text: 4.D: Explain the degree to which a model or representation describes the connection between particulate-level properties and macroscopic properties.
